description: From Middle English samoun, samon, saumon, from Anglo-Norman saumon, from Old French saumon, from Latin salmō, salmōn-. Displaced native Middle English lax, from Old English leax. The unpronounced l was later inserted to make the word appear closer to its Latin root (compare words like debt, indict, receipt, island for the same spelling Latinizations).

examples: Smiley and Guillam perched disconsolately beneath it, on a bench of salmon velvet.

entries.meaning: One of several species of fish, typically of the Salmoninae subfamily, brownish above with silvery sides and delicate pinkish-orange flesh; they ascend rivers to spawn.
A meal or dish made from this fish.
(plural salmons) A pale pinkish-orange colour, the colour of cooked salmon.
The upper bricks in a kiln which receive the least heat.
(Cockney rhyming slang) snout (tobacco; from salmon and trout)

verbs.description: salmon (third-person singular simple present salmons, present participle salmoning, simple past and past participle salmoned)

entries.meaning: (slang, intransitive) To ride a bicycle the wrong way down a one-way street.
examples: Some cities discourage salmoning with clever signage, like this in London: "If you can read this you are biking the wrong way."
